interlinear-text.item: ELA Comparing the Wakhis of Afghanistan and Tajikistan [3]

phrase.item: Since 2011 I started traveling in the Wakhan [Corridor], on the Afghanistan side.
My trip to Afghanistan was a dream for me, to see our Wakhi people on the other side. With God willing, I went there.
Later, I went there several times.
There are similarities and differences, but wherever our Wakhi people may be, we are very nice people,
we are very pure.
Wherever you go, our Wakhi people are quite friendly. We are simple and respectful people.

In terms of language in Afghanistan, just as with us Wakhis in Tajikistan, how our [language] has the influence of the Tajik and Russian languages, so do those Wakhi speakers in the Afghan Wakhan, have a big influence in their language from Persian.
They use many Farsi [Dari] words.
I thought our Wakhis, more on the Afghanistan side, would probably have been more traditional and kept the culture.
However, when I saw them, they have not kept their culture and tradition as I thought.
As we traveled all the way to Sarhad, Pinja and all the way down [Afghanistan], for all our musical instruments, for example, rubab, very few people make and carve them, very few people.
But I saw a good thing there, our traditional songs, such as bilbilik, or the playing of the daf [traditional frame drum] and singing, and traditional dances are well preserved there.
When I went to Sarhad I saw that males were also singing bilbilik.

Males also sing the old traditional bilbilik that is passed to us from our mothers and grandmothers. They have been using them. At weddings and any events, they would mix the [bilbilik] with songs and sing them.
It's great that the old bilbilik are able to live again [in use].
People will start using them again.
There are also some traditions they have forgotten.
For example, our traditional hat is famous on the Tajikistan side of Wakhan. On the Afghan Wakhan side, I didn't see them sewing the hats [by hand].
For making anything, they use sewing machines. So, there are customs [traditional crafts] they have not kept.
I thought the bride and groom when they make [a wedding there], would wear the outfits that were used by our grandparents,
all handmade, including dress and pants, such as handmade chapan [coat] and all that.
But I didn't see such things there, everyone was wearing suits and pants everyone was modern.
In terms of skills and [handicraft] things to be honest I saw very few people who were interested in knitting socks, or sewing hats or making baskets.
I saw very few people interested in such things.
I also realized that many things are Chinese there,
and by comparison our people [are more likely to] make them by hand.

Thankfully, today when we go to Wakhan in Tajikistan, our [clothing] stores where our sisters and brothers sell goods you can also find there handmade Wakhi hats, and you see that they are selling the Wakhi hats.
It's very good that we haven't forgotten our culture. Instead, we are keeping our traditions and bringing them to life again. Whenever foreigners come to our place, they also buy them.
Using our skills, culture and traditions, we also benefit from them.
That's amazing work.
I want our brothers who are in the Afghan Wakhan also to do their best not to forget their culture and traditions.
All the skills and other things that have passed to us from ancient times. Bring them back to life again, and it will also help them to earn something on the side, as a living.
